set.p: The action takes place at Aston-Adey , Arnold Champion-Cheney 's house in Dorset .

div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: The Scene is a stately drawing-room at Aston-Adey , with fine pictures on the walls and Georgian furniture . Aston-Adey has been described , with many illustrations , in Country Life . It is not a house , but a place . Its owner takes a great pride in it , and there is nothing in the room which is not of the period . Through the French windows at the back can be seen the beautiful gardens which are one of the features .
It is a fine summer morning .

ARNOLD comes in . He is a man of about thirty-five , tall and good-looking , fair , with a clean-cut , sensitive face . He has a look that is intellectual , but somewhat bloodless . He is very well dressed .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Calling .Elizabeth !He goes to the window and calls again .Elizabeth !He rings the bell . While he is waiting he gives a look round the room . He slightly alters the position of one of the chairs . He takes an ornament from the chimney-piece and blows the dust from it .A FOOTMAN comes in .Oh , George ! see if you can find Mrs. Cheney , and ask her if she 'd be good enough to come here .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: The FOOTMAN turns to go .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Who is supposed to look after this room ?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: I do n't know , sir .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I wish when they dust they 'd take care to replace the things exactly as they were before .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Dismissing him .All right .

div.stage: The FOOTMAN goes out . He goes again to the window and calls .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Elizabeth !He sees MRS. SHENSTONE .Oh , Anna , do you know where Elizabeth is ?

div.stage: MRS. SHENSTONE comes in from the garden . She is a woman of forty , pleasant and of elegant appearance .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Is n't she playing tennis ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No , I 've been down to the tennis court . Something very tiresome has happened .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I wonder where the deuce she is .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: When do you expect Lord Porteous and Lady Kitty ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: They 're motoring down in time for luncheon .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Are you sure you want me to be here ? It 's not too late yet , you know . I can have my things packed and catch a train for somewhere or other .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No , of course we want you . It 'll make it so much easier if there are people here . It was exceedingly kind of you to come .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Oh , nonsense !

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: And I think it was a good thing to have Teddie Luton down .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: He is so breezy , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Yes , that 's his great asset . I do n't know that he 's very intelligent , but , you know , there are occasions when you want a bull in a china shop . I sent one of the servants to find Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I daresay she 's putting on her shoes . She and Teddie were going to have a single .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It can n't take all this time to change one 's shoes .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: With a smile .One can n't change one 's shoes without powdering one 's nose , you know .

div.stage: ELIZABETH comes in . She is a very pretty creature in the early twenties . She wears a light summer frock .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My dear , I 've been hunting for you everywhere . What have you been doing ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Nothing ! I 've been standing on my head .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My father 's here .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Startled .Where ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: At the cottage . He arrived last night .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Damn !

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Good-humouredly .I wish you would n't say that , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: If you 're not going to say “ Damn ” when a thing 's damnable , when are you going to say “ Damn ” ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I should have thought you could say , “ Oh , bother ! ” or something like that .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But that would n't express my sentiments . Besides , at that speech day when you were giving away the prizes you said there were no synonyms in the English language .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Smiling .Oh , Elizabeth ! it 's very unfair to expect a politician to live in private up to the statements he makes in public .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm always willing to stand by anything I 've said . There are no synonyms in the English language .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: In that case I shall be regretfully forced to continue to say “ Damn ” whenever I feel like it .

div.stage: EDWARD LUTON shows himself at the window . He is an attractive youth in flannels .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I say , what about this tennis ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Come in . We 're having a scene .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Entering .How splendid ! What about ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: The English language .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Do n't tell me you 've been splitting your infinitives .

lg.stage: With the shadow of a frown .
lg.l: I wish you 'd be serious ,
Elizabeth . The situation is none too pleasant .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I think Teddie and I had better make ourselves scarce .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Nonsense ! You 're both in it . If there 's going to be any unpleasantness we want your moral support . That 's why we asked you to come .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: And I thought I 'd been asked for my blue eyes .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Vain beast ! And they happen to be brown .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Is anything up ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Arnold 's father arrived last night .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Did he , by Jove ! I thought he was in Paris .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: So did we all . He told me he 'd be there for the next month .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Have you seen him ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No ! he rang me up . It 's a mercy he had a telephone put in the cottage . It would have been a pretty kettle of fish if he 'd just walked in .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Did you tell him Lady Catherine was coming ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Of course not . I was flabbergasted to know he was here . And then I thought we 'd better talk it over first .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Is he coming along here ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Yes . He suggested it , and I could n't think of any excuse to prevent him .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Could n't you put the other people off ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: They 're coming by car . They may be here any minute . It 's too late to do that .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Besides , it would be beastly .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I knew it was silly to have them here . Elizabeth insisted .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: After all , she is your mother , Arnold .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: That meant precious little to her when she — went away . You can n't imagine it means very much to me now .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's thirty years ago . It seems so absurd to bear malice after all that time .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I do n't bear malice , but the fact remains that she did me the most irreparable harm . I can find no excuse for her .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Have you ever tried to ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My dear Elizabeth , it 's no good going over all that again . The facts are lamentably simple . She had a husband who adored her , a wonderful position , all the money she could want , and a child of five . And she ran away with a married man .

lg.l: Lady Porteous is not a very attractive woman , Arnold .
Do you know her ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Smiling .“ Forbidding ” is the word , I think .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: If you 're going to make little jokes about it , I have nothing more to say .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I 'm sorry , Arnold .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Perhaps your mother could n't help herself — if she was in love ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: And had no sense of honour , duty , or decency ? Oh , yes , under those circumstances you can explain a great deal .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That 's not a very pretty way to speak of your mother .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I can n't look on her as my mother .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What you can n't get over is that she did n't think of you . Some of us are more mother and some of us more woman . It gives me a little thrill when I think that she loved that man so much . She sacrificed her name , her position , and her child to him .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: You really can n't expect the said child to have any great affection for the mother who treated him like that .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , I do n't think I do . But I think it 's a pity after all these years that you should n't be friends .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I wonder if you realise what it was to grow up under the shadow of that horrible scandal . Everywhere , at school , and at Oxford , and afterwards in London , I was always the son of Lady Kitty Cheney . Oh , it was cruel , cruel !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes , I know , Arnold . It was beastly for you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It would have been bad enough if it had been an ordinary case , but the position of the people made it ten times worse . My father was in the House then , and Porteous — he had n't succeeded to the title — was in the House too ; he was Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs , and he was very much in the public eye .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: My father always used to say he was the ablest man in the party . Every one was expecting him to be Prime Minister .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: You can imagine what a boon it was to the British public . They had n't had such a treat for a generation . The most popular song of the day was about my mother . Did you ever hear it ? “ Naughty Lady Kitty . Thought it such a pity . . . ”

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Interrupting .Oh , Arnold , do n't !

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: And then they never let people forget them . If they 'd lived quietly in Florence and not made a fuss the scandal would have died down . But those constant actions between Lord and Lady Porteous kept on reminding everyone .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: What were they having actions about ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Of course my father divorced his wife , but Lady Porteous refused to divorce Porteous . He tried to force her by refusing to support her and turning her out of her house , and heaven knows what . They were constantly wrangling in the law courts .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I think it was monstrous of Lady Porteous .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: She knew he wanted to marry my mother , and she hated my mother . You can n't blame her .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: It must have been very difficult for them .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: That 's why they 've lived in Florence . Porteous has money . They found people there who were willing to accept the situation .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: This is the first time they 've ever come to England .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My father will have to be told , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: To ELIZABETH .Has he ever spoken to you about Lady Kitty ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I do n't think her name has passed his lips since she ran away from this house thirty years ago .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , they lived here ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Naturally . There was a house-party , and one evening neither Porteous nor my mother came down to dinner . The rest of them waited . They could n't make it out . My father sent up to my mother 's room , and a note was found on the pincushion .

lg.l: That 's what they did in the Dark
Ages .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I think he took a dislike to this house from that horrible night . He never lived here again , and when I married he handed the place over to me . He just has a cottage now on the estate that he comes to when he feels inclined .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's been very nice for us .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I owe everything to my father . I do n't think he 'll ever forgive me for asking these people to come here .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm going to take all the blame on myself , Arnold .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Irritably .The situation was embarrassing enough anyhow . I do n't know how I ought to treat them .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do n't you think that 'll settle itself when you see them ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: After all , they 're my guests . I shall try and behave like a gentleman .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I would n't . We have n't got central heating .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Taking no notice .Will she expect me to kiss her ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a smile .Surely .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It always makes me uncomfortable when people are effusive .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: But I can n't understand why you never saw her before .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I believe she tried to see me when I was little , but my father thought it better she should n't .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes , but when you were grown up ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: She was always in Italy . I never went to Italy .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It seems to me so pathetic that if you saw one another in the street you would n't recognise each other .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Is it my fault ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 've promised to be very gentle with her and very kind .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: The mistake was asking Porteous to come too . It looks as though we condoned the whole thing . And how am I to treat him ? Am I to shake him by the hand and slap him on the back ? He absolutely ruined my father 's life .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling .How much would you give for a nice motor accident that prevented them from coming ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I let you persuade me against my better judgment , and I 've regretted it ever since .

lg.l: I think it 's very lucky that Anna and
Teddie are here . I do n't foresee a very successful party .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm going to do my best . I gave you my promise and I shall keep it . But I can n't answer for my father .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Here is your father .

div.stage: MR. CHAMPION-CHENEY shows himself at one of the French windows .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: May I come in through the window , or shall I have myself announced by a supercilious flunkey ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Come in . We 've been expecting you .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Impatiently , I hope , my dear child .

div.stage: MR. CHAMPION-CHENEY is a tall man in the early sixties , spare , with a fine head of gray hair and an intelligent , somewhat ascetic face . He is very carefully dressed . He is a man who makes the most of himself . He bears his years jauntily . He kisses ELIZABETH and then holds out his hand to ARNOLD .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: We thought you 'd be in Paris for another month .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: How are you , Arnold ? I always reserve to myself the privilege of changing my mind . It 's the only one elderly gentlemen share with pretty women .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You know Anna .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Shaking hands with her .Of course I do . How very nice to see you here ! Are you staying long ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: As long as I 'm welcome .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: And this is Mr. Luton .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: How do you do ? Do you play bridge ?

sp.speaker: LUTON
sp.p: I do .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Capital . Do you declare without top honours ?

sp.speaker: LUTON
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Of such is the kingdom of heaven . I see that you are a good young man .

sp.speaker: LUTON
sp.p: But , like the good in general , I am poor .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Never mind ; if your principles are right , you can play ten shillings a hundred without danger . I never play less , and I never play more .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: And you — are you going to stay long , father ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: To luncheon , if you 'll have me .

div.stage: ARNOLD gives ELIZABETH a harassed look .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That 'll be jolly .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I did n't mean that . Of course you 're going to stay for luncheon . I meant , how long are you going to stay down here ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: A week .

div.stage: There is a moment 's pause . Everyone but CHAMPION-CHENEY is slightly embarrassed .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I think we 'd better chuck our tennis .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes . I want my father-in-law to tell me what they 're wearing in Paris this week .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 'll go and put the rackets away .

div.stage: TEDDIE goes out .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's nearly one o'clock , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I did n't know it was so late .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: To ARNOLD .I wonder if I can persuade you to take a turn in the garden before luncheon .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Jumping at the idea .I 'd love it .ANNA goes out of the window , and as he follows her he stops irresolutely .I want you to look at this chair I 've just got . I think it 's rather good .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Charming .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: About 1750 , I should say . Good design , is n't it ? It has n't been restored or anything .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Very pretty .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I think it was a good buy , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Oh , my dear boy ! you know I 'm entirely ignorant about these things .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's exactly my period . . . I shall see you at luncheon , then .

div.stage: He follows ANNA through the window .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Who is that young man ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Mr. Luton . He 's only just been demobilised . He 's the manager of a rubber estate in the F. M. S .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: And what are the F. M. S . when they 're at home ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: The Federated Malay States . He joined up at the beginning of the war . He 's just going back there .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: And why have we been left alone in this very marked manner ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Have we ? I did n't notice it .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I suppose it 's difficult for the young to realise that one may be old without being a fool .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I never thought you that . Everyone knows you 're very intelligent .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: They certainly ought to by now . I 've told them often enough . Are you a little nervous ?

lg.l: Let me feel my pulse .
lg.stage: She puts her finger on her wrist .
lg.l: It 's perfectly regular .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: When I suggested staying to luncheon Arnold looked exactly like a dose of castor oil .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wish you 'd sit down .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Will it make it easier for you ?He takes a chair .You have evidently something very disagreeable to say to me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You wo n't be cross with me ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: How old are you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Twenty-five .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'm never cross with a woman under thirty .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , then I 've got ten years .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Mathematics ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No . Paint .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Reflectively .I think it would be easier if I sat on your knees .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: That is a pleasing taste of yours , but you must take care not to put on weight .

div.stage: She sits down on his knees .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Am I boney ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: On the contrary . . . . I 'm listening .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Lady Catherine 's coming here .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Who 's Lady Catherine ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Your — Arnold 's mother .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Is she ?

div.stage: He withdraws himself a little and ELIZABETH gets up .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You must n't blame Arnold . It 's my fault . I insisted . He was against it . I nagged him till he gave way . And then I wrote and asked her to come .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I did n't know you knew her .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't . But I heard she was in London . She 's staying at Claridge 's . It seemed so heartless not to take the smallest notice of her .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: When is she coming ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: We 're expecting her in time for luncheon .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: As soon as that ? I understand the embarrassment .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You see , we never expected you to be here . You said you 'd be in Paris for another month .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear child , this is your house . There 's no reason why you should n't ask whom you please to stay with you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: After all , whatever her faults , she 's Arnold 's mother . It seemed so unnatural that they should never see one another . My heart ached for that poor lonely woman .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I never heard that she was lonely , and she certainly is n't poor .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: And there 's something else . I could n't ask her by herself . It would have been so — so insulting . I asked Lord Porteous , too .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I daresay you 'd rather not meet them .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I daresay they 'd rather not meet me . I shall get a capital luncheon at the cottage . I 've noticed you always get the best food if you come in unexpectedly and have the same as they 're having in the servants ’ hall .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No one 's ever talked to me about Lady Kitty . It 's always been a subject that everyone has avoided . I 've never even seen a photograph of her .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: The house was full of them when she left . I think I told the butler to throw them in the dust-bin . She was very much photographed .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Wo n't you tell me what she was like ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She was very like you , Elizabeth , only she had dark hair instead of red .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Poor dear ! it must be quite white now .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I daresay . She was a pretty little thing .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But she was one of the great beauties of her day . They say she was lovely .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She had the most adorable little nose , like yours . . . .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: D'you like my nose ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: And she was very dainty , with a beautiful little figure ; very light on her feet . She was like a marquise in an old French comedy . Yes , she was lovely .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: And I 'm sure she 's lovely still .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She 's no chicken , you know .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You can n't expect me to look at it as you and Arnold do . When you 've loved as she 's loved you may grow old , but you grow old beautifully .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You 're very romantic .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: If everyone had n't made such a mystery of it I daresay I should n't feel as I do . I know she did a great wrong to you and a great wrong to Arnold . I 'm willing to acknowledge that .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'm sure it 's very kind of you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But she loved and she dared . Romance is such an illusive thing . You read of it in books , but it 's seldom you see it face to face . I can n't help it if it thrills me .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I am painfully aware that the husband in these cases is not a romantic object .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: She had the world at her feet . You were rich . She was a figure in society . And she gave up everything for love .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Dryly .I 'm beginning to suspect it was n't only for her sake and for Arnold 's that you asked her to come here .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I seem to know her already . I think her face is a little sad , for a love like that does n't leave you gay , it leaves you grave , but I think her pale face is unlined . It 's like a child 's .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear , how you let your imagination run away with you !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I imagine her slight and frail .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Frail , certainly .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With beautiful thin hands and white hair . I 've pictured her so often in that Renaissance Palace that they live in , with old Masters on the walls and lovely carved things all round , sitting in a black silk dress with old lace round her neck and old-fashioned diamonds . You see , I never knew my mother ; she died when I was a baby . You can n't confide in aunts with huge families of their own . I want Arnold 's mother to be a mother to me . I 've got so much to say to her .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Are you happy with Arnold ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Why should n't I be ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Why have n't you got any babies ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Give us a little time . We 've only been married three years .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I wonder what Hughie is like now !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Lord Porteous ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He wore his clothes better than any man in London . You know he 'd have been Prime Minister if he 'd remained in politics .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What was he like then ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He was a nice-looking fellow . Fine horseman . I suppose there was something very fascinating about him . Yellow hair and blue eyes , you know . He had a very good figure . I liked him . I was his parliamentary secretary . He was Arnold 's godfather .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I wonder if he ever regrets !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I would n't .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Well , I must be strolling back to my cottage .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 're not angry with me ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Not a bit .

div.stage: She puts up her face for him to kiss . He kisses her on both cheeks and then goes out . In a moment TEDDIE is seen at the window .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I saw the old blighter go .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Come in .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Everything all right ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , quite , as far as he 's concerned . He 's going to keep out of the way .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Was it beastly ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , he made it very easy for me . He 's a nice old thing .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You were rather scared .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: A little . I am still . I do n't know why .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I guessed you were . I thought I 'd come and give you a little moral support . It 's ripping here , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It is rather nice .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: It 'll be jolly to think of it when I 'm back in the F. M. S .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Are n't you homesick sometimes ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , everyone is now and then , you know .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You could have got a job in England if you 'd wanted to , could n't you ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , but I love it out there . England 's ripping to come back to , but I could n't live here now . It 's like a woman you 're desperately in love with as long as you do n't see her , but when you 're with her she maddens you so that you can n't bear her .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling .What 's wrong with England ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I do n't think anything 's wrong with England . I expect something 's wrong with me . I 've been away too long . England seems to me full of people doing things they do n't want to because other people expect it of them .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Is n't that what you call a high degree of civilisation ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: People seem to me so insincere . When you go to parties in London they 're all babbling about art , and you feel that in their hearts they do n't care twopence about it . They read the books that everybody is talking about because they do n't want to be out of it . In the F. M. S . we do n't get very many books , and we read those we have over and over again . They mean so much to us . I do n't think the people over there are half so clever as the people at home , but one gets to know them better . You see , there are so few of us that we have to make the best of one another .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I imagine that frills are not much worn in the F. M. S . It must be a comfort .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: It 's not much good being pretentious where everyone knows exactly who you are and what your income is .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't think you want too much sincerity in society . It would be like an iron girder in a house of cards .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: And then , you know , the place is ripping . You get used to a blue sky and you miss it in England .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What do you do with yourself all the time ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , one works like blazes . You have to be a pretty hefty fellow to be a planter . And then there 's ripping bathing . You know , it 's lovely , with palm trees all along the beach . And there 's shooting . And now and then we have a little dance to a gramophone .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Pretending to tease him .I think you 've got a young woman out there , Teddie .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Vehemently .Oh , no !

div.stage: She is a little taken aback by the earnestness of his disclaimer . There is a moment 's silence , then she recovers herself .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But you 'll have to marry and settle down one of these days , you know .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I want to , but it 's not a thing you can do lightly .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't know why there more than elsewhere .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: In England if people do n't get on they go their own ways and jog along after a fashion . In a place like that you 're thrown a great deal on your own resources .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Lots of girls come out because they think they 're going to have a good time . But if they 're empty-headed , then they 're just faced with their own emptiness and they 're done . If their husbands can afford it they go home and settle down as grass-widows .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 've met them . They seem to find it a very pleasant occupation .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: It 's rotten for their husbands , though .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: And if the husbands can n't afford it ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , then they tipple .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's not a very alluring prospect .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: But if the woman 's the right sort she would n't exchange it for any life in the world . When all 's said and done it 's we who 've made the Empire .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What sort is the right sort ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: A woman of courage and endurance and sincerity . Of course , it 's hopeless unless she 's in love with her husband .

div.stage: He is looking at her earnestly and she , raising her eyes , gives him a long look . There is silence between them .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: My house stands on the side of a hill , and the cocoanut trees wind down to the shore . Azaleas grow in my garden , and camellias , and all sorts of ripping flowers . And in front of me is the winding coast line , and then the blue sea .A pause .Do you know that I 'm awfully in love with you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Gravely .I was n't quite sure . I wondered .

lg.l: And you ?
I 've never kissed you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't want you to .

div.stage: They look at one another steadily . They are both grave . ARNOLD comes in hurriedly .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: They 're coming , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: As though returning from a distant world .Who ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Impatiently .My dear ! My mother , of course . The car is just coming up the drive .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Would you like me to clear out ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No , no ! For goodness ’ sake stay .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: We 'd better go and meet them , Arnold .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No , no ; I think they 'd much better be shown in . I feel simply sick with nervousness .

div.stage: ANNA comes in from the garden .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Your guests have arrived .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes , I know .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 've given orders that luncheon should be served at once .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Why ? It 's not half-past one already , is it ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I thought it would help . When you do n't know exactly what to say you can always eat .

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in and announces .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Lady Catherine Champion-Cheney ! Lord Porteous !

div.stage: LADY KITTY comes in followed by PORTEOUS , and the BUTLER goes out . LADY KITTY is a gay little lady , with dyed red hair and painted cheeks . She is somewhat outrageously dressed . She never forgets that she has been a pretty woman and she still behaves as if she were twenty-five . LORD PORTEOUS is a very bald , elderly gentleman in loose , rather eccentric clothes . He is snappy and gruff . This is not at all the couple that ELIZABETH expected , and for a moment she stares at them with round , startled eyes . LADY KITTY goes up to her with outstretched hands .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Elizabeth ! Elizabeth !She kisses her effusively .What an adorable creature !Turning to PORTEOUS .Hughie , is n't she adorable ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: With a grunt .Ugh !

div.stage: ELIZABETH , smiling now , turns to him and gives him her hand .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Damnable road you 've got down here . How d'you do , my dear ? Why d'you have such damnable roads in England ?

div.stage: LADY KITTY 'S eyes fall on TEDDIE and she goes up to him with her arms thrown back , prepared to throw them round him .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My boy , my boy ! I should have known you anywhere !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Hastily .That 's Arnold .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Without a moment 's hesitation .The image of his father ! I should have known him anywhere !She throws her arms round his neck .My boy , my boy !

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: With a grunt .Ugh !

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Tell me , would you have known me again ? Have I changed ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I was only five , you know , when — when you . . .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Emotionally .I remember as if it was yesterday . I went up into your room .With a sudden change of manner .By the way , I always thought that nurse drank . Did you ever find out if she really did ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: How the devil can you expect him to know that , Kitty ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You 've never had a child , Hughie ; how can you tell what they know and what they do n't ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Coming to the rescue .This is Arnold , Lord Porteous .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .How d'you do ? I knew your father .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Alive still ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: He must be getting on . Is he well ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Ugh ! Takes care of himself , I suppose . I 'm not at all well . This damned climate does n't agree with me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: To LADY KITTY .This is Mrs. Shenstone . And this is Mr. Luton . I hope you do n't mind a very small party .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Shaking hands with ANNA and TEDDIE .Oh , no , I shall enjoy it . I used to give enormous parties here . Political , you know . How nice you 've made this room !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , that 's Arnold .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Nervously .D'you like this chair ? I 've just bought it . It 's exactly my period .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Bluntly .It 's a fake .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Indignantly .I do n't think it is for a minute .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: The legs are not right .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I do n't know how you can say that . If there is anything right about it , it 's the legs .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 'm sure they 're right .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You know nothing whatever about it , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: That 's what you think . I think it 's a beautiful chair . Hepplewhite ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No , Sheraton .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , I know . “ The School for Scandal . ”

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Sheraton , my dear . Sheraton .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Yes , that 's what I say . I acted the screen scene at some amateur theatricals in Florence , and Ermeto Novelli , the great Italian tragedian , told me he 'd never seen a Lady Teazle like me .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Ugh !

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: To ELIZABETH .Do you act ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , I could n't . I should be too nervous .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 'm never nervous . I 'm a born actress . Of course , if I had my time over again I 'd go on the stage . You know , it 's extraordinary how they keep young . Actresses , I mean . I think it 's because they 're always playing different parts . Hughie , do you think Arnold takes after me or after his father ? Of course I think he 's the very image of me . Arnold , I think I ought to tell you that I was received into the Catholic Church last winter . I 'd been thinking about it for years , and last time we were at Monte Carlo I met such a nice monsignore . I told him what my difficulties were and he was too wonderful . I knew Hughie would n't approve , so I kept it a secret .To ELIZABETH .Are you interested in religion ? I think it 's too wonderful . We must have a long talk about it one of these days .Pointing to her frock .Callot ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , Worth .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I knew it was either Worth or Callot . Of course , it 's line that 's the important thing . I go to Worth myself , and I always say to him , “ Line , my dear Worth , line . ” What is the matter , Hughie ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: These new teeth of mine are so damned uncomfortable .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Men are extraordinary . They can n't stand the smallest discomfort . Why , a woman 's life is uncomfortable from the moment she gets up in the morning till the moment she goes to bed at night . And d'you think it 's comfortable to sleep with a mask on your face ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: They do n't seem to hold up properly .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Well , that 's not the fault of your teeth . That 's the fault of your gums .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Damned rotten dentist . That 's what 's the matter .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I thought he was a very nice dentist . He told me my teeth would last till I was fifty . He has a Chinese room . It 's so interesting ; while he scrapes your teeth he tells you all about the dear Empress Dowager . Are you interested in China ? I think it 's too wonderful . You know they 've cut off their pigtails . I think it 's such a pity . They were so picturesque .

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Luncheon is served , sir .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Would you like to see your rooms ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: We can see our rooms after luncheon .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I must powder my nose , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Powder it down here .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I never saw anyone so inconsiderate .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You 'll keep us all waiting half an hour . I know you .

lg.l: Oh , well , peace at any price , as
Lord Beaconsfield said .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: He said a lot of damned silly things , Kitty , but he never said that .

div.stage: LADY KITTY 'S face changes . Perplexity is followed by dismay , and dismay by consternation .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What is the matter ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: With anguish .My lip-stick !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Ca n't you find it ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I had it in the car . Hughie , you remember that I had it in the car .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't remember anything about it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do n't be so stupid , Hughie . Why , when we came through the gates I said : “ My home , my home ! ” and I took it out and put some on my lips .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Perhaps you dropped it in the car .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: For heaven 's sake send some one to look for it .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'll ring .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 'm absolutely lost without my lip-stick . Lend me yours , darling , will you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm awfully sorry . I 'm afraid I have n't got one .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do you mean to say you do n't use a lip-stick ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Look at her lips . What the devil d'you think she wants muck like that for ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , what a mistake you make ! You must use a lip-stick . It 's so good for the lips . Men like it , you know . I could n't live without a lip-stick .

div.stage: CHAMPION-CHENEY appears at the window holding in his upstretched hand a little gold case .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: As he comes in .Has anyone here lost a diminutive utensil containing , unless I am mistaken , a favourite preparation for the toilet ?

div.stage: ARNOLD and ELIZABETH are thunderstruck at his appearance and even TEDDIE and ANNA are taken aback . But LADY KITTY is overjoyed .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My lip-stick !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I found it in the drive and I ventured to bring it in .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's Saint Antony . I said a little prayer to him when I was hunting in my bag .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Saint Antony be blowed ! It 's Clive , by God !

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Startled , her attention suddenly turning from the lip-stick .Clive !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You did n't recognise me . It 's many years since we met .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My poor Clive , your hair has gone quite white !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Holding out his hand .I hope you had a pleasant journey down from London .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Offering him her cheek .You may kiss me , Clive .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Kissing her .You do n't mind , Hughie ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: With a grunt .Ugh !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Going up to him cordially .And how are you , my dear Hughie ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Damned rheumatic if you want to know . Filthy climate you have in this country .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Are n't you going to shake hands with me , Hughie ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I have no objection to shaking hands with you .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You 've aged , my poor Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Some one was asking me how old you were the other day .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Were they surprised when you told them ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Surprised ! They wondered you were n't dead .

div.stage: The BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Did you ring , sir ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No . Oh , yes , I did . It does n't matter now .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: As the BUTLER is going .One moment . My dear Elizabeth , I 've come to throw myself on your mercy . My servants are busy with their own affairs . There 's not a thing for me to eat in my cottage .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , but we shall be delighted if you 'll lunch with us .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It either means that or my immediate death from starvation . You do n't mind , Arnold ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My dear father !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: To the BUTLER .Mr. Cheney will lunch here .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Very good , ma'am .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: To LADY KITTY .And what do you think of Arnold ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I adore him .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He 's grown , has n't he ? But then you 'd expect him to do that in thirty years .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: For God 's sake let 's go in to lunch , Elizabeth ! END OF THE FIRST ACT

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The Scene is the same as in the preceding Act .
It is afternoon . When the curtain rises PORTEOUS and LADY KITTY , ANNA and TEDDIE are playing bridge . ELIZABETH and CHAMPION-CHENEY are watching . PORTEOUS and LADY KITTY are partners .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: When will Arnold be back , Elizabeth ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Soon , I think .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Is he addressing a meeting ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , it 's only a conference with his agent and one or two constituents .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Irritably .How anyone can be expected to play bridge when people are shouting at the top of their voices all round them , I for one cannot understand .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling .I 'm so sorry .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I can see your hand , Lord Porteous .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: It may help you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 've told you over and over again to hold your cards up . It ruins one 's game when one can n't help seeing one 's opponent 's hand .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: One is n't obliged to look .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: What was Arnold 's majority at the last election ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Seven hundred and something .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He 'll have to fight for it if he wants to keep his seat next time .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Are we playing bridge , or talking politics ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I never find that conversation interferes with my game .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You certainly play no worse when you talk than when you hold your tongue .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I think that 's a very offensive thing to say , Hughie . Just because I do n't play the same game as you do you think I can n't play .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I 'm glad you acknowledge it 's not the same game as I play . But why in God 's name do you call it bridge ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I agree with Kitty . I hate people who play bridge as though they were at a funeral and knew their feet were getting wet .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Of course you take Kitty 's part .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: That 's the least he can do .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I have a naturally cheerful disposition .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You 've never had anything to sour it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I do n't know what you mean by that , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Trying to contain himself .Must you trump my ace ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Innocently .Oh , was that your ace , darling ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Furiously .Yes , it was my ace .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , well , it was the only trump I had . I should n't have made it anyway .

lg.l: You need n't have told them that . Now she knows exactly what
I 've got .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: She knew before .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: How could she know ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: She said she 'd seen your hand .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Oh , I did n't . I said I could see it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Well , I naturally supposed that if she could see it she did .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Really , Kitty , you have the most extraordinary ideas .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Not at all . If anyone is such a fool as to show me his hand , of course I look at it .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Fuming .If you study the etiquette of bridge , you 'll discover that onlookers are expected not to interfere with the game .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear Hughie , this is a matter of ethics , not of bridge .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Anyhow , I get the game . And rubber .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I claim a revoke .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Who revoked ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You did .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Nonsense . I 've never revoked in my life .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 'll show you .He turns over the tricks to show the faces of the cards .You threw away a club on the third heart trick and you had another heart .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I never had more than two hearts .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , yes , you had . Look here . That 's the card you played on the last trick but one .

lg.l: There 's no doubt about it ,
Hughie . You revoked .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I tell you I did not revoke . I never revoke .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You did , Hughie . I wondered what on earth you were doing .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't know how anyone can be expected not to revoke when there 's this confounded chatter going on all the time .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Well , that 's another hundred to us .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: To CHAMPION-CHENEY .I wish you would n't breathe down my neck . I never can play bridge when there 's somebody breathing down my neck .

div.stage: The party have risen from the bridge-table , and they scatter about the room .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Well , I 'm going to take a book and lie down in the hammock till it 's time to dress .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Who has been adding up .I 'll put it down in the book , shall I ?

lg.stage: Who has not moved , setting out the cards for a patience .
lg.l: Yes , yes , put it down . I never revoke .

div.stage: ANNA goes out .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Would you like to come for a little stroll , Hughie ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Exercise .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I hate exercise .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Looking at the patience .The seven goes on the eight .

div.stage: PORTEOUS takes no notice .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: The seven goes on the eight , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't choose to put the seven on the eight .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: That knave goes on the queen .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I 'm not blind , thank you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: The three goes on the four .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: All these go over .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Furiously .Am I playing this patience , or are you playing it ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: But you 're missing everything .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: That 's my business .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It 's no good losing your temper over it , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Go away , both of you . You irritate me .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: We were only trying to help you , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't want to be helped . I want to do it by myself .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I think your manners are perfectly deplorable , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: It 's simply maddening when you 're playing patience and people wo n't leave you alone .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: We wo n't say another word .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: That three goes . I believe it 's coming out . If I 'd been such a fool as to put that seven up I should n't have been able to bring these down .He puts down several cards while they watch him silently .LADY KITTY and C. - C .Together .The four goes on the five .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Throwing down the cards violently .Damn you ! why do n't you leave me alone ? It 's intolerable .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It was coming out , my dear fellow .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I know it was coming out . Confound you !

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: How petty you are , Hughie !

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Petty , be damned ! I 've told you over and over again that I will not be interfered with when I 'm playing patience .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do n't talk to me like that , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I shall talk to you as I please .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Beginning to cry .Oh , you brute ! You brute !She flings out of the room .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Oh , damn ! now she 's going to cry .

div.stage: He shambles out into the garden . CHAMPION-CHENEY , ELIZABETH and TEDDIE are left alone . There is a moment 's pause . CHAMPION-CHENEY looks from TEDDIE to ELIZABETH , with an ironical smile .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Upon my soul , they might be married . They frip so much .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Frigidly .It 's been nice of you to come here so often since they arrived . It 's helped to make things easy .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Irony ? It 's a rhetorical form not much favoured in this blessed plot , this earth , this realm , this England .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What exactly are you getting at ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: How slangy the young women of the present day are ! I suppose the fact that Arnold is a purist leads you to the contrary extravagance .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Anyhow you know what I mean .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: With a smile .I have a dim , groping suspicion .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You promised to keep away . Why did you come back the moment they arrived ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Curiosity , my dear child . A surely pardonable curiosity .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: And since then you 've been here all the time . You do n't generally favour us with so much of your company when you 're down at your cottage .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 've been excessively amused .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It has struck me that whenever they started fripping you took a malicious pleasure in goading them on .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I do n't think there 's much love lost between them now , do you ?

div.stage: TEDDIE is making as though to leave the room .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do n't go , Teddie .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: No , please do n't . I 'm only staying a minute . We were talking about Lady Kitty just before she arrived .To ELIZABETH .Do you remember ? The pale , frail lady in black satin and old lace .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a chuckle .You are a devil , you know .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Ah , well , he 's always had the reputation of being a humorist and a gentleman .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Did you expect her to be like that , poor dear ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear child , I had n't the vaguest idea . You were asking me the other day what she was like when she ran away . I did n't tell you half . She was so gay and so natural . Who would have thought that animation would turn into such frivolity , and that charming impulsiveness lead to such a ridiculous affectation ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It rather sets my nerves on edge to hear the way you talk of her .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It 's the truth that sets your nerves on edge , not I .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You loved her once . Have you no feeling for her at all ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: None . Why should I ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: She 's the mother of your son .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear child , you have a charming nature , as simple , frank , and artless as hers was . Do n't let pure humbug obscure your common sense .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: We have no right to judge . She 's only been here two days . We know nothing about her .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear , her soul is as thickly rouged as her face . She has n't an emotion that 's sincere . She 's tinsel . You think I 'm a cruel , cynical old man . Why , when I think of what she was , if I did n't laugh at what she has become I should cry .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: How do you know she would n't be just the same now if she 'd remained your wife ? Do you think your influence would have had such a salutary effect on her ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Good-humouredly .I like you when you 're bitter and rather insolent .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: D'you like me enough to answer my question ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She was only twenty-seven when she went away . She might have become anything . She might have become the woman you expected her to be . There are very few of us who are strong enough to make circumstances serve us . We are the creatures of our environment . She 's a silly , worthless woman because she 's led a silly , worthless life .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Disturbed .You 're horrible to-day .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I do n't say it 's I who could have prevented her from becoming this ridiculous caricature of a pretty woman grown old . But life could . Here she would have had the friends fit to her station , and a decent activity , and worthy interests . Ask her what her life has been all these years among divorced women and kept women and the men who consort with them . There is no more lamentable pursuit than a life of pleasure .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: At all events she loved and she loved greatly . I have only pity and affection for her .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: And if she loved what d'you think she felt when she saw that she had ruined Hughie ? Look at him . He was tight last night after dinner and tight the night before .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: And she took it as a matter of course . How long do you suppose he 's been getting tight every night ? Do you think he was like that thirty years ago ? Can you imagine that that was a brilliant young man , whom everyone expected to be Prime Minister ? Look at him now . A grumpy sodden old fellow with false teeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You have false teeth , too .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Yes , but damn it all , they fit . She 's ruined him and she knows she 's ruined him .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Looking at him suspiciously .Why are you saying all this to me ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Am I hurting your feelings ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I think I 've had enough for the present .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'll go and have a look at the gold-fish . I want to see Arnold when he comes in .Politely .I 'm afraid we 've been boring Mr. Luton .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: When are you going back to the F. M. S . ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: In about a month .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I see .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wonder what he has at the back of his head .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: D'you think he was talking at you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He 's as clever as a bagful of monkeys .

div.stage: There is a moment 's pause . TEDDIE hesitates a little and when he speaks it is in a different tone . He is grave and somewhat nervous .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: It seems very difficult to get a few minutes alone with you . I wonder if you 've been making it difficult ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wanted to think .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 've made up my mind to go away to-morrow .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I want you altogether or not at all .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 're so arbitrary .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You said you — you said you cared for me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Do you mind if we talk it over now ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Frowning .It makes me feel rather shy and awkward . I 've repeated to myself over and over again exactly what I want to say to you , and now all I 'd prepared seems rather footling .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm so afraid I 'm going to cry .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I feel it 's all so tremendously serious and I think we ought to keep emotion out of it . You 're rather emotional , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Half smiling and half in tears .So are you for the matter of that .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: That 's why I wanted to have everything I meant to say to you cut and dried . I think it would be awfully unfair if I made love to you and all that sort of thing , and you were carried away . I wrote it all down and thought I 'd send it you as a letter .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Why did n't you ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I got the wind up . A letter seems so — so cold . You see , I love you so awfully .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake do n't say that .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You must n't cry . Please do n't , or I shall go all to pieces .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Trying to smile .I 'm sorry . It does n't mean anything really . It 's only tears running out of my eyes .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Our only chance is to be awfully matter-of-fact .

div.stage: He stops for a moment . He finds it quite difficult to control himself . He clears his throat . He frowns with annoyance at himself .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 've got a sort of lump in my throat . It is idiotic . I think I 'll have a cigarette .She watches him in silence while he lights a cigarette .You see , I 've never been in love with anyone before , not really . It 's knocked me endways . I do n't know how I can live without you now . . . . Does that old fool know I 'm in love with you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I think so .

lg.l: When he was talking about Lady Kitty smashing up Lord
Porteous ’ career I thought there was something at the back of it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I think he was trying to persuade me not to smash up yours .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 'm sure that 's very considerate of him , but I do n't happen to have one to smash . I wish I had . It 's the only time in my life I 've wished I were a hell of a swell so that I could chuck it all and show you how much more you are to me than anything else in the world .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Affectionately .You 're a dear old thing , Teddie .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You know , I do n't really know how to make love , but if I did I could n't do it now because I just want to be absolutely practical .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Chaffing him .I 'm glad you do n't know how to make love . It would be almost more than I could bear .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You see , I 'm not at all romantic and that sort of thing . I 'm just a common or garden business man . All this is so dreadfully serious and I think we ought to be sensible .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a break in her voice .You owl !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: No , Elizabeth , do n't say things like that to me . I want you to consider all the pros and cons , and my heart 's thumping against my chest , and you know I love you , I love you , I love you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: In a sigh of passion .Oh , my precious !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Impatiently , but with himself , rather than with ELIZABETH .Do n't be idiotic , Elizabeth . I 'm not going to tell you that I can n't live without you and a lot of muck like that . You know that you mean everything in the world to me .Almost giving it up as a bad job .Oh , my God !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Her voice faltering .D'you think there 's anything you can say to me that I do n't know already ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Desperately .But I have n't said a single thing I wanted to . I 'm a business man and I want to put it all in a business way , if you understand what I mean .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling .I do n't believe you 're a very good business man .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Sharply .You do n't know what you 're talking about . I 'm a first-rate business man , but somehow this is different .Hopelessly .I do n't know why it wo n't go right .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What are we going to do about it ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You see , it 's not just because you 're awfully pretty that I love you . I 'd love you just as much if you were old and ugly . It 's you I love , not what you look like . And it 's not only love ; love be blowed ! It 's that I like you so tremendously . I think you 're such a ripping good sort . I just want to be with you . I feel so jolly and happy just to think you 're there . I 'm so awfully fond of you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Laughing through her tears .I do n't know if this is your idea of introducing a business proposition .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Damn you , you wo n't let me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You said “ Damn you . ”

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I meant it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Your voice sounded as if you meant it , you perfect duck !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Really , Elizabeth , you 're intolerable .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm doing nothing .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Yes , you are , you 're putting me off my blow . What I want to say is perfectly simple . I 'm a very ordinary business man .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 've said that before .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Angrily .Shut up . I have n't got a bob besides what I earn . I 've got no position . I 'm nothing . You 're rich and you 're a big pot and you 've got everything that anyone can want . It 's awful cheek my saying anything to you at all . But after all there 's only one thing that really matters in the world , and that 's love . I love you . Chuck all this , Elizabeth , and come to me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Are you cross with me ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Furious .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Darling !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: If you do n't want me tell me so at once and let me get out quickly .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Teddie , nothing in the world matters anything to me but you . I 'll go wherever you take me . I love you .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: All to pieces .Oh , my God !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Does it mean as much to you as that ? Oh , Teddie !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Trying to control himself .Do n't be a fool , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's you 're the fool . You 're making me cry .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You 're so damned emotional .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Damned emotional yourself . I 'm sure you 're a rotten business man .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I do n't care what you think . You 've made me so awfully happy . I say , what a lark life 's going to be !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Teddie , you are an angel .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Let 's get out quick . It 's no good wasting time . Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Nothing . I just like to say Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You fool !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I say , can you shoot ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 'll teach you . You do n't know how ripping it is to start out from your camp at dawn and travel through the jungle . And you 're so tired at night and the sky 's all starry . It 's a fair treat . Of course I did n't want to say anything about all that till you 'd decided . I 'd made up my mind to be absolutely practical .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Chaffing him .The only practical thing you said was that love is the only thing that really matters .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Happily .Pull the other leg next time , will you ? I should have to have one longer than the other .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Is n't it fun being in love with some one who 's in love with you ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I say , I think I 'd better clear out at once , do n't you ? It seems rather rotten to stay on in — in this house .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You can n't go to-night . There 's no train .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 'll go to-morrow . I 'll wait in London till you 're ready to join me .

lg.l: I 'm not going to leave a note on the pincushion like Lady
Kitty , you know . I 'm going to tell Arnold .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Are you ? Do n't you think there 'll be an awful bother ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I must face it . I should hate to be sly and deceitful .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Well , then , let 's face it together .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , I 'll talk to Arnold by myself .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You wo n't let anyone influence you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No .

div.stage: He holds out his hand and she takes it . They look into one another 's eyes with grave , almost solemn affection . There is the sound outside of a car driving up .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: There 's the car . Arnold 's come back . I must go and bathe my eyes . I do n't want them to see I 've been crying .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: All right .As she is going .Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Stopping .What ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Bless you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Affectionately .Idiot !

div.stage: She goes out of the door and TEDDIE through the French window into the garden . For an instant the room is empty . ARNOLD comes in . He sits down and takes some papers out of his despatch-case . LADY KITTY enters . He gets up .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I saw you come in . Oh , my dear , do n't get up . There 's no reason why you should be so dreadfully polite to me .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 've just rung for a cup of tea .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Perhaps we shall have the chance of a little talk . We do n't seem to have had five minutes by ourselves . I want to make your acquaintance , you know .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I should like you to know that it 's not by my wish that my father is here .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: But I 'm so interested to see him .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I was afraid that you and Lord Porteous must find it embarrassing .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , no . Hughie was his greatest friend . They were at Eton and Oxford together . I think your father has improved so much since I saw him last . He was n't good-looking as a young man , but now he 's quite handsome .

div.stage: The FOOTMAN brings in a tray on which are tea-things .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Shall I pour it out for you ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Thank you very much .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do you take sugar ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No . I gave it up during the war .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: So wise of you . It 's so bad for the figure . Besides being patriotic , of course . Is n't it absurd that I should ask my son if he takes sugar or not ? Life is really very quaint . Sad , of course , but oh , so quaint ! Often I lie in bed at night and have a good laugh to myself as I think how quaint life is .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm a very serious person .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: How old are you now , Arnold ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Thirty-five .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Are you really ? Of course , I was a child when I married your father .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Really . He always told me you were twenty-two .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , what nonsense ! Why , I was married out of the nursery . I put my hair up for the first time on my wedding-day .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Where is Lord Porteous ?

lg.l: My dear , it sounds too absurd to hear you call him Lord
Porteous . Why do n't you call him — Uncle Hughie ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: He does n't happen to be my uncle .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: No , but he 's your godfather . You know , I 'm sure you 'll like him when you know him better . I 'm so hoping that you and Elizabeth will come and stay with us in Florence . I simply adore Elizabeth . She 's too beautiful .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Her hair is very pretty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's not touched up , is it ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Oh , no .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I just wondered . It 's rather a coincidence that her hair should be the same colour as mine . I suppose it shows that your father and you are attracted by just the same thing . So interesting , heredity , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Of course , since I joined the Catholic Church I do n't believe in it any more . Darwin and all that sort of thing . Too dreadful . Wicked , you know . Besides , it 's not very good form , is it ?

div.stage: CHAMPION-CHENEY comes in from the garden .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Do I intrude ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Come in , Clive . Arnold and I have been having such a wonderful heart-to-heart talk .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Very nice .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Father , I stepped in for a moment at the Harveys ’ on my way back . It 's simply criminal what they 're doing with that house .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: What are they doing ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's an almost perfect Georgian house and they 've got a lot of dreadful Victorian furniture . I gave them my ideas on the subject , but it 's quite hopeless . They said they were attached to their furniture .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Arnold should have been an interior decorator .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: He has wonderful taste . He gets that from me .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I suppose I have a certain flair . I have a passion for decorating houses .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You 've made this one charming .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: D'you remember , we just had chintzes and comfortable chairs when we lived here , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Perfectly hideous , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: In those days gentlemen and ladies were not expected to have taste .

lg.l: You know , I 've been looking at this chair again . Since Lord
Porteous said the legs were n't right I 've been very uneasy .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: He only said that because he was in a bad temper .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: His temper seems to me very short these days , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , it is .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: You feel he knows what he 's talking about . I gave seventy-five pounds for that chair . I 'm very seldom taken in . I always think if a thing 's right you feel it .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Well , do n't let it disturb your night 's rest .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: But , my dear father , that 's just what it does . I had a most horrible dream about it last night .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Here is Hughie .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm going to fetch a book I have on Old English furniture . There 's an illustration of a chair which is almost identical with this one .

div.stage: PORTEOUS comes in .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Quite a family gathering , by George !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I was thinking just now we 'd make a very pleasing picture of a typical English home .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'll be back in five minutes . There 's something I want to show you , Lord Porteous .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Would you like to play piquet with me , Hughie ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Not particularly .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You were never much of a piquet player , were you ?

lg.l: My dear Clive , you people do n't know what piquet is in
England .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Let 's have a game then . You may make money .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't want to play with you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I do n't know why not , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Let me tell you that I do n't like your manner .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'm sorry for that . I 'm afraid I can n't offer to change it at my age .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't know what you want to be hanging around here for .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: A natural attachment to my home .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: If you 'd had any tact you 'd have kept out of the way while we were here .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear Hughie , I do n't understand your attitude at all . If I 'm willing to let bygones be bygones why should you object ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Damn it all , they 're not bygones .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: After all , I am the injured party .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: How the devil are you the injured party ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Well , you did run away with my wife , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Now , do n't let 's go into ancient history . I can n't see why we should n't all be friends .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I beg you not to interfere , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 'm very fond of Clive .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You never cared two straws for Clive . You only say that to irritate me .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Not at all . I do n't see why he should n't come and stay with us .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'd love to . I think Florence in spring-time is delightful . Have you central heating ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I never liked you , I do n't like you now , and I never shall like you .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: How very unfortunate ! because I liked you , I like you now , and I shall continue to like you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: There 's something very nice about you , Clive .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: If you think that , why the devil did you leave him ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Are you going to reproach me because I loved you ? How utterly , utterly , utterly detestable you are !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Now , now , do n't quarrel with one another .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's all his fault . I 'm the easiest person in the world to live with . But really he 'd try the patience of a saint .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Come , come , do n't get upset , Kitty . When two people live together there must be a certain amount of give and take .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I do n't know what the devil you 're talking about .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It has n't escaped my observation that you are a little inclined to frip . Many couples are . I think it 's a pity .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Would you have the very great kindness to mind your own business ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It is his business . He naturally wants me to be happy .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I have the very greatest affection for Kitty .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Then why the devil did n't you look after her properly ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear Hughie , you were my greatest friend . I trusted you . It may have been rash .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: It was inexcusable .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I do n't know what you mean by that , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Do n't , do n't , do n't try and bully me , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , I know what you mean .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Then why the devil did you say you did n't ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: When I think that I sacrificed everything for that man ! And for thirty years I 've had to live in a filthy marble palace with no sanitary conveniences .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: D'you mean to say you have n't got a bathroom ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 've had to wash in a tub .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My poor Kitty , how you 've suffered !

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Really , Kitty , I 'm sick of hearing of the sacrifices you made . I suppose you think I sacrificed nothing . I should have been Prime Minister by now if it had n't been for you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Nonsense !

lg.l: What do you mean by that ? Everyone said I should be Prime
Minister . Should n't I have been Prime Minister , Clive ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It was certainly the general expectation .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I was the most promising young man of my day . I was bound to get a seat in the Cabinet at the next election .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: They 'd have found you out just as I 've found you out . I 'm sick of hearing that I ruined your career . You never had a career to ruin . Prime Minister ! You have n't the brain . You have n't the character .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Cheek , push , and a gift of the gab will serve very well instead , you know .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Besides , in politics it 's not the men that matter . It 's the women at the back of them . I could have made Clive a Cabinet Minister if I 'd wanted to .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Clive ?
