sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: With my beauty , my charm , my force of character , my wit , I could have done anything .

lg.l: Clive was nothing but my political secretary . When I was
Prime Minister I might have made him Governor of some Colony or other .
Western Australia , say . Out of pure kindliness .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: With flashing eyes .D'you think I would have buried myself in Western Australia ? With my beauty ? My charm ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Or Barbadoes , perhaps .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Furiously .Barbadoes ! Barbadoes can go to — Barbadoes .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: That 's all you 'd have got .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Nonsense ! I 'd have India .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I would never have given you India .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You would have given me India .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I tell you I would n't .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: The King would have given me India . The nation would have insisted on my having India . I would have been a vice-reine or nothing .

lg.l: I tell you that as long as the interests of the British
Empire — Damn it all , my teeth are coming out !

div.stage: He hurries from the room .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's too much . I can n't bear it any more . I 've put up with him for thirty years and now I 'm at the end of my tether .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Calm yourself , my dear Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I wo n't listen to a word . I 've quite made up my mind . It 's finished , finished , finished .With a change of tone .I was so touched when I heard that you never lived in this house again after I left it .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: The cuckoos have always been very plentiful . Their note has a personal application which , I must say , I have found extremely offensive .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: When I saw that you did n't marry again I could n't help thinking that you still loved me .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I am one of the few men I know who is able to profit by experience .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: In the eyes of the Church I am still your wife . The Church is so wise . It knows that in the end a woman always comes back to her first love . Clive , I am willing to return to you .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear Kitty , I could n't take advantage of your momentary vexation with Hughie to let you take a step which I know you would bitterly regret .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You 've waited for me a long time . For Arnold 's sake .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Do you think we really need bother about Arnold ? In the last thirty years he 's had time to grow used to the situation .

lg.l: I think I 've sown my wild oats ,
Clive .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I have n't . I was a good young man , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I know .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: And I 'm very glad , because it has enabled me to be a wicked old one .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

div.stage: ARNOLD comes in with a large book in his hand .

lg.l: I say , I 've found the book I was hunting for . Oh ! is n't Lord
Porteous here ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: One moment , Arnold . Your father and I are busy .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm so sorry .

div.stage: He goes out into the garden .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Explain yourself , Clive .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: When you ran away from me , Kitty , I was sore and angry and miserable . But above all I felt a fool .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Men are so vain .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: But I was a student of history , and presently I reflected that I shared my misfortune with very nearly all the greatest men .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I 'm a great reader myself . It has always struck me as peculiar .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: The explanation is very simple . Women dislike intelligence , and when they find it in their husbands they revenge themselves on them in the only way they can , by making them — well , what you made me .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's ingenious . It may be true .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I felt I had done my duty by society and I determined to devote the rest of my life to my own entertainment . The House of Commons had always bored me excessively and the scandal of our divorce gave me an opportunity to resign my seat . I have been relieved to find that the country got on perfectly well without me .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: But has love never entered your life ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Tell me frankly , Kitty , do n't you think people make a lot of unnecessary fuss about love ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's the most wonderful thing in the world .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You 're incorrigible . Do you really think it was worth sacrificing so much for ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My dear Clive , I do n't mind telling you that if I had my time over again I should be unfaithful to you , but I should not leave you .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: For some years I was notoriously the prey of a secret sorrow . But I found so many charming creatures who were anxious to console that in the end it grew rather fatiguing . Out of regard to my health I ceased to frequent the drawing-rooms of Mayfair .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: And since then ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Since then I have allowed myself the luxury of assisting financially a succession of dear little things , in a somewhat humble sphere , between the ages of twenty and twenty-five .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I cannot understand the infatuation of men for young girls . I think they 're so dull .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It 's a matter of taste . I love old wine , old friends and old books , but I like young women . On their twenty-fifth birthday I give them a diamond ring and tell them they must no longer waste their youth and beauty on an old fogey like me . We have a most affecting scene , my technique on these occasions is perfect , and then I start all over again .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You 're a wicked old man , Clive .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: That 's what I told you . But , by George ! I 'm a happy one .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: There 's only one course open to me now .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: With a flashing smile .To go and dress for dinner .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Capital . I will follow your example .

div.stage: As LADY KITTY goes out ELIZABETH comes in .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Where is Arnold ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He 's on the terrace . I 'll call him .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do n't bother .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I was just strolling along to my cottage to put on a dinner jacket .As he goes out .Arnold .

div.stage: Exit C. - C .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Hulloa !He comes in .Oh , Elizabeth , I 've found an illustration here of a chair which is almost identical with mine . It 's dated 1750 . Look !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That 's very interesting .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I want to show it to Porteous .Moving a chair which has been misplaced .You know , it does exasperate me the way people will not leave things alone . I no sooner put a thing in its place than somebody moves it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It must be maddening for you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It is . You are the worst offender . I can n't think why you do n't take the pride that I do in the house . After all , it 's one of the show places in the county .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm afraid you find me very unsatisfactory .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Good-humouredly .I do n't know about that . But my two subjects are politics and decoration . I should be a perfect fool if I did n't see that you do n't care two straws about either .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: We have n't very much in common , Arnold , have we ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I do n't think you can blame me for that .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't . I blame you for nothing . I have no fault to find with you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Surprised at her significant tone .Good gracious me ! what 's the meaning of all this ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Well , I do n't think there 's any object in beating about the bush . I want you to let me go .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Go where ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Away . For always .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My dear child , what are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I want to be free .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Amused rather than disconcerted .Do n't be ridiculous , darling . I daresay you 're run down and want a change . I 'll take you over to Paris for a fortnight if you like .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I should n't have spoken to you if I had n't quite made up my mind . We 've been married for three years and I do n't think it 's been a great success . I 'm frankly bored by the life you want me to lead .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Well , if you 'll allow me to say so , the fault is yours . We lead a very distinguished , useful life . We know a lot of extremely nice people .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm quite willing to allow that the fault is mine . But how does that make it any better ? I 'm only twenty-five . If I 've made a mistake I have time to correct it .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I can n't bring myself to take you very seriously .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You see , I do n't love you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Well , I 'm awfully sorry . But you were n't obliged to marry me . You 've made your bed and I 'm afraid you must lie on it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That 's one of the falsest proverbs in the English language . Why should you lie on the bed you 've made if you do n't want to ? There 's always the floor .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: For goodness ’ sake do n't be funny , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 've quite made up my mind to leave you , Arnold .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Come , come , Elizabeth , you must be sensible . You have n't any reason to leave me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Why should you wish to keep a woman tied to you who wants to be free ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I happen to be in love with you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You might have said that before .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I thought you 'd take it for granted . You can n't expect a man to go on making love to his wife after three years . I 'm very busy . I 'm awfully keen on politics and I 've worked like a dog to make this house a thing of beauty . After all , a man marries to have a home , but also because he does n't want to be bothered with sex and all that sort of thing . I fell in love with you the first time I saw you and I 've been in love ever since .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm sorry , but if you 're not in love with a man his love does n't mean very much to you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's so ungrateful . I 've done everything in the world for you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 've been very kind to me . But you 've asked me to lead a life I do n't like and that I 'm not suited for . I 'm awfully sorry to cause you pain , but now you must let me go .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Nonsense ! I 'm a good deal older than you are and I think I have a little more sense . In your interests as well as in mine I 'm not going to do anything of the sort .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a smile .How can you prevent me ? You can n't keep me under lock and key .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Please do n't talk to me as if I were a foolish child . You 're my wife and you 're going to remain my wife .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What sort of a life do you think we should lead ? Do you think there 'd be any more happiness for you than for me ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: But what is it precisely that you suggest ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Well , I want you to let me divorce you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Astounded .Me ? Thank you very much . Are you under the impression I 'm going to sacrifice my career for a whim of yours ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: How will it do that ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My seat 's wobbly enough as it is . Do you think I 'd be able to hold it if I were in a divorce case ? Even if it were a put-up job , as most divorces are nowadays , it would damn me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's rather hard on a woman to be divorced .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: With sudden suspicion .What do you mean by that ? Are you in love with some one ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Teddie Luton .

div.stage: He is astonished for a moment , then bursts into a laugh .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My poor child , how can you be so ridiculous ? Why , he has n't a bob . He 's a perfectly commonplace young man . It 's so absurd I can n't even be angry with you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 've fallen desperately in love with him , Arnold .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Well , you 'd better fall desperately out .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He wants to marry me .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I daresay he does . He can go to hell .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's no good talking like that .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Is he your lover ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , certainly not .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It shows that he 's a mean skunk to take advantage of my hospitality to make love to you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He 's never even kissed me .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'd try telling that to the horse marines if I were you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's because I wanted to do nothing shabby that I told you straight out how things were .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: How long have you been thinking of this ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 've been in love with Teddie ever since I knew him .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: And you never thought of me at all , I suppose .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , yes , I did . I was miserable . But I can n't help myself . I wish I loved you , but I do n't .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I recommend you to think very carefully before you do anything foolish .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I have thought very carefully .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: By God ! I do n't know why I do n't give you a sound hiding . I 'm not sure if that would n't be the best thing to bring you to your senses .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , Arnold , do n't take it like that .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: How do you expect me to take it ? You come to me quite calmly and say : “ I 've had enough of you . We 've been married three years and I think I 'd like to marry somebody else now . Shall I break up your home ? What a bore for you ! Do you mind my divorcing you ? It 'll smash up your career , will it ? What a pity ! ” Oh , no , my girl , I may be a fool , but I 'm not a damned fool .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Teddie is leaving here by the first train to-morrow . I warn you that I mean to join him as soon as he can make the necessary arrangements .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Where is he ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't know . I suppose he 's in his room .

div.stage: ARNOLD goes to the door and calls .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: George !

div.stage: For a moment he walks up and down the room impatiently . ELIZABETH watches him . The FOOTMAN comes in .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Tell Mr. Luton to come here at once .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Ask Mr. Luton if he would n't mind coming here for a moment .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Very good , madam .

div.stage: Exit FOOTMAN .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What are you going to say to him ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: That 's my business .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I would n't make a scene if I were you .

lg.l: I 'm not going to make a scene .
Why did you insist on my mother coming here ?
It seemed to me rather absurd to take up the attitude that
I should be contaminated by her when . . .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Interrupting .When you were proposing to do exactly the same thing . Well , now you 've seen her what do you think of her ? Do you think it 's been a success ? Is that the sort of woman a man would like his mother to be ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 've been ashamed . I 've been so sorry . It all seemed dreadful and horrible . This morning I happened to notice a rose in the garden . It was all overblown and bedraggled . It looked like a painted old woman . And I remembered that I 'd looked at it a day or two ago . It was lovely then , fresh and blooming and fragrant . It may be hideous now , but that does n't take away from the beauty it had once . That was real .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Poetry , by God ! As if this were the moment for poetry !

div.stage: TEDDIE comes in . He has changed into a dinner jacket .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: To ELIZABETH .Did you want me ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I sent for you .TEDDIE looks from ARNOLD to ELIZABETH . He sees that something has happened .When would it be convenient for you to leave this house ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I was proposing to go to-morrow morning . But I can very well go at once if you like .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I do like .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Very well . Is there anything else you wish to say to me ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Do you think it was a very honourable thing to come down here and make love to my wife ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: No , I do n't . I have n't been very happy about it . That 's why I wanted to go away .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Upon my word you 're cool .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 'm afraid it 's no good saying I 'm sorry and that sort of thing . You know what the situation is .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Is it true that you want to marry Elizabeth ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Yes . I should like to marry her as soon as ever I can .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Have you thought of me at all ? Has it struck you that you 're destroying my home and breaking up my happiness ?

lg.l: I do n't see how there could be much happiness for you if
Elizabeth does n't care for you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Let me tell you that I refuse to have my home broken up by a twopenny-halfpenny adventurer who takes advantage of a foolish woman . I refuse to allow myself to be divorced . I can n't prevent my wife from going off with you if she 's determined to make a damned fool of herself , but this I tell you : nothing will induce me to divorce her .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Arnold , that would be monstrous .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: We could force you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: If we went away together openly you 'd have to bring an action .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Twenty-four hours after you leave this house I shall go down to Brighton with a chorus-girl . And neither you nor I will be able to get a divorce . We 've had enough divorces in our family . And now get out , get out , get out !

div.stage: TEDDIE looks uncertainly at ELIZABETH .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a little smile .Do n't bother about me . I shall be all right .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Get out ! Get out ! END OF THE SECOND ACT

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: The Scene is the same as in the preceding Acts .
It is the night of the same day as that on which takes place the action of the second Act .
CHAMPION-CHENEY and ARNOLD , both in dinner jackets , are discovered . CHAMPION-CHENEY is seated . ARNOLD walks restlessly up and down the room .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I think , if you 'll follow my advice to the letter , you 'll probably work the trick .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I do n't like it , you know . It 's against all my principles .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: My dear Arnold , we all hope that you have before you a distinguished political career . You can n't learn too soon that the most useful thing about a principle is that it can always be sacrificed to expediency .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: But supposing it does n't come off ? Women are incalculable .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Nonsense ! Men are romantic . A woman will always sacrifice herself if you give her the opportunity . It is her favourite form of self-indulgence .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I never know whether you 're a humorist or a cynic , father .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'm neither , my dear boy ; I 'm merely a very truthful man . But people are so unused to the truth that they 're apt to mistake it for a joke or a sneer .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Irritably .It seems so unfair that this should happen to me .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Keep your head , my boy , and do what I tell you .

div.stage: LADY KITTY and ELIZABETH come in . LADY KITTY is in a gorgeous evening gown .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Where is Lord Porteous ?

lg.l: He 's on the terrace . He 's smoking a cigar .
Hughie !

div.stage: PORTEOUS comes in .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: With a grunt .Yes ? Where 's Mrs. Shenstone ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , she had a headache . She 's gone to bed .

div.stage: When PORTEOUS comes in LADY KITTY with a very haughty air purses her lips and takes up an illustrated paper . PORTEOUS gives her an irritated look , takes another illustrated paper and sits himself down at the other end of the room . They are not on speaking terms .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Arnold and I have just been down to my cottage .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wondered where you 'd gone .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I came across an old photograph album this afternoon . I meant to bring it along before dinner , but I forgot , so we went and fetched it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , do let me see it ! I love old photographs .

div.stage: He gives her the album , and she , sitting down , puts it on her knees and begins to turn over the pages . He stands over her . LADY KITTY and PORTEOUS take surreptitious glances at one another .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I thought it might amuse you to see what pretty women looked like five-and-thirty years ago . That was the day of beautiful women .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do you think they were more beautiful then than they are now ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Oh , much . Now you see lots of pretty little things , but very few beautiful women .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Are n't their clothes funny ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Pointing to a photograph .That 's Mrs. Langtry .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: She has a lovely nose .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She was the most wonderful thing you ever saw . Dowagers used to jump on chairs in order to get a good look at her when she came into a drawing-room . I was riding with her once , and we had to have the gates of the livery stable closed when she was getting on her horse because the crowd was so great .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: And who 's that ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Lady Lonsdale . That 's Lady Dudley .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: This is an actress , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It is , indeed . Ellen Terry . By George ! how I loved that woman !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a smile .Dear Ellen Terry !

lg.l: That 's Bwabs . I never saw a smarter man in my life . And Oliver
Montagu . Henry Manners with his eye-glass .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Nice-looking , is n't he ? And this ?

lg.l: That 's Mary Anderson . I wish you could have seen her in “ A
Winter 's Tale . ” Her beauty just took your breath away . And look !
There 's Lady Randolph . Bernal Osborne — the wittiest man I ever knew .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I think it 's too sweet . I love their absurd bustles and those tight sleeves .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: What figures they had ! In those days a woman was n't supposed to be as thin as a rail and as flat as a pancake .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , but are n't they laced in ? How could they bear it ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: They did n't play golf then , and nonsense like that , you know . They hunted , in a tall hat and a long black habit , and they were very gracious and charitable to the poor in the village .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Did the poor like it ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: They had a very thin time if they did n't . When they were in London they drove in the Park every afternoon , and they went to ten-course dinners , where they never met anybody they did n't know . And they had their box at the opera when Patti was singing or Madame Albani .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , what a lovely little thing ! Who on earth is that ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: That ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: She looks so fragile , like a piece of exquisite china , with all those furs on and her face up against her muff , and the snow falling .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Yes , there was quite a rage at that time for being taken in an artificial snowstorm .

lg.l: What a sweet smile , so roguish and frank , and debonair ! Oh ,
I wish I looked like that ! Do tell me who it is !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Do n't you know ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Why — it 's Kitty .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Lady Kitty !To LADY KITTY .Oh , my dear , do look ! It 's too ravishing .She takes the album over to her impulsively .Why did n't you tell me you looked like that ? Everybody must have been in love with you .

div.stage: LADY KITTY takes the album and looks at it . Then she lets it slip from her hands and covers her face with her hands . She is crying .
In consternation . ] My dear , what 's the matter ? Oh , what have I done ? I 'm so sorry .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do n't , do n't talk to me . Leave me alone . It 's stupid of me .

div.stage: ELIZABETH looks at her for a moment perplexed , then , turning round , slips her arm in CHAMPION-CHENEY 's and leads him out on to the terrace .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: As they are going , in a whisper .Did you do that on purpose ?

div.stage: PORTEOUS gets up and goes over to LADY KITTY . He puts his hand on her shoulder . They remain thus for a little while .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I 'm afraid I was very rude to you before dinner , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Taking his hand which is on her shoulder .It does n't matter . I 'm sure I was very exasperating .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I did n't mean what I said , you know .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Neither did I .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Of course I know that I 'd never have been Prime Minister .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: How can you talk such nonsense , Hughie ? No one would have had a chance if you 'd remained in politics .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I have n't the character .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You have more character than anyone I 've ever met .

lg.l: Besides , I do n't know that I much wanted to be Prime
Minister .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , but I should have been so proud of you . Of course you 'd have been Prime Minister .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I 'd have given you India , you know . I think it would have been a very popular appointment .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I do n't care twopence about India . I 'd have been quite content with Western Australia .

lg.l: My dear , you do n't think I 'd have let you bury yourself in
Western Australia ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Or Barbadoes .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Never . It sounds like a cure for flat feet . I 'd have kept you in London .

div.stage: He picks up the album and is about to look at the photograph of LADY KITTY . She puts her hand over it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: No , do n't look .

div.stage: He takes her hand away .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Do n't be so silly .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Is n't it hateful to grow old ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You know , you have n't changed much .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Enchanted .Oh , Hughie , how can you talk such nonsense ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Of course you 're a little more mature , but that 's all . A woman 's all the better for being rather mature .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do you really think that ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Upon my soul I do .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You 're not saying it just to please me ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: No , no .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Let me look at the photograph again .She takes the album and looks at the photograph complacently .The fact is , if your bones are good , age does n't really matter . You 'll always be beautiful .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: With a little smile , almost as if he were talking to a child .It was silly of you to cry .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It has n't made my eyelashes run , has it ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Not a bit .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It 's very good stuff I use now . They do n't stick together either .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Look here , Kitty , how much longer do you want to stay here ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , I 'm quite ready to go whenever you like .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Clive gets on my nerves . I do n't like the way he keeps hanging about you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Surprised , rather amused , and delighted .Hughie , you do n't mean to say you 're jealous of poor Clive ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Of course I 'm not jealous of him , but he does look at you in a way that I can n't help thinking rather objectionable .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Hughie , you may throw me downstairs like Amy Robsart ; you may drag me about the floor by the hair of my head ; I do n't care , you 're jealous . I shall never grow old .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Damn it all , the man was your husband .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My dear Hughie , he never had your style . Why , the moment you come into a room everyone looks and says : “ Who the devil is that ? ”

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: What ? You think that , do you ? Well , I daresay there 's something in what you say . These damned Radicals can say what they like , but , by God , Kitty ! when a man 's a gentleman — well , damn it all , you know what I mean .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I think Clive has degenerated dreadfully since we left him .

lg.l: What do you say to making a bee-line for Italy and going to
San Michele ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , Hughie ! It 's years since we were there .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Would n't you like to see it again — just once more ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Do you remember the first time we went ? It was the most heavenly place I 'd ever seen . We 'd only left England a month , and I said I 'd like to spend all my life there .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Of course I remember . And in a fortnight it was yours , lock , stock and barrel .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: We were very happy there , Hughie .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Let 's go back once more .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I dare n't . It must be all peopled with the ghosts of our past . One should never go again to a place where one has been happy . It would break my heart .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Do you remember how we used to sit on the terrace of the old castle and look at the Adriatic ? We might have been the only people in the world , you and I , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Tragically .And we thought our love would last for ever .

div.stage: Enter CHAMPION-CHENEY .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Is there any chance of bridge this evening ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I do n't think we can make up a four .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: What a nuisance that boy went away like that ! He was n't a bad player .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Teddie Luton ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I think it was very funny his going without saying good-bye to anyone .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: The young men of the present day are very casual .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I thought there was no train in the evening .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: There is n't . The last train leaves at 5. 45 .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: How did he go then ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He went .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Damned selfish I call it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Intrigued .Why did he go , Clive ?

div.stage: CHAMPION-CHENEY looks at her for a moment reflectively .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I have something very grave to say to you . Elizabeth wants to leave Arnold .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Clive ! What on earth for ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She 's in love with Teddie Luton . That 's why he went . The men of my family are really very unfortunate .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Does she want to run away with him ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: With consternation .My dear , what 's to be done ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I think you can do a great deal .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I ? What ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Tell her , tell her what it means .

div.stage: He looks at her fixedly . She stares at him .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , no , no !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She 's a child . Not for Arnold 's sake . For her sake . You must .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You do n't know what you 're asking .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Yes , I do .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Hughie , what shall I do ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Do what you like . I shall never blame you for anything .

div.stage: The FOOTMAN comes in with a letter on a salver . He hesitates on seeing that ELIZABETH is not in the room .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: I was looking for Mrs. Champion-Cheney , sir .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: She 's not here . Is that a letter ?

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Yes , sir . It 's just been sent up from the “ Champion Arms . ”

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Leave it . I 'll give it to Mrs. Cheney .

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: He brings the tray to CLIVE , who takes the letter . The FOOTMAN goes out .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Is the “ Champion Arms ” the local pub ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Looking at the letter .It 's by way of being a hotel , but I never heard of anyone staying there .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: If there was no train I suppose he had to go there .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Great minds . I wonder what he has to write about !He goes to the door leading on to the garden .Elizabeth !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Outside .Yes .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Here 's a note for you .

div.stage: There is silence . They wait for ELIZABETH to come . She enters .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's lovely in the garden to-night .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: They 've just sent this up from the “ Champion Arms . ”

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: Without embarrassment she opens the letter . They watch her while she reads it . It covers three pages . She puts it away in her bag .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Hughie , I wish you 'd fetch me a cloak . I 'd like to take a little stroll in the garden , but after thirty years in Italy I find these English summers rather chilly .Without a word PORTEOUS goes out . ELIZABETH is lost in thought .I want to talk to Elizabeth , Clive .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I 'll leave you .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: What does he say ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Mr. Luton .

lg.stage: Gives a little start . Then she looks at LADY KITTY .
lg.l: They 've told you ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Yes . And now they have I think I knew it all along .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't expect you to have much sympathy for me . Arnold is your son .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: So pitifully little .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm not suited for this sort of existence . Arnold wants me to take what he calls my place in Society . Oh , I get so bored with those parties in London . All those middle-aged painted women , in beautiful clothes , lolloping round ball-rooms with rather old young men . And the endless luncheons where they gossip about so-and-so 's love affairs .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Are you very much in love with Mr. Luton ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I love him with all my heart .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: And he ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He 's never cared for anyone but me . He never will .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Will Arnold let you divorce him ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , he wo n't hear of it . He refuses even to divorce me .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He thinks a scandal will revive all the old gossip .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , my poor child !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It can n't be helped . I 'm quite willing to accept the consequences .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You do n't know what it is to have a man tied to you only by his honour . When married people do n't get on they can separate , but if they 're not married it 's impossible . It 's a tie that only death can sever .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: If Teddie stopped caring for me I should n't want him to stay with me for five minutes .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: One says that when one 's sure of a man 's love , but when one is n't any more — oh , it 's so different . In those circumstances one 's got to keep a man 's love . It 's the only thing one has .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm a human being . I can stand on my own feet .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Have you any money of your own ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: None .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Then how can you stand on your own feet ? You think I 'm a silly , frivolous woman , but I 've learned something in a bitter school . They can make what laws they like , they can give us the suffrage , but when you come down to bedrock it 's the man who pays the piper who calls the tune . Woman will only be the equal of man when she earns her living in the same way that he does .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling .It sounds rather funny to hear you talk like that .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: A cook who marries a butler can snap her fingers in his face because she can earn just as much as he can . But a woman in your position and a woman in mine will always be dependent on the men who keep them .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't want luxury . You do n't know how sick I am of all this beautiful furniture . These over-decorated houses are like a prison in which I can n't breathe . When I drive about in a Callot frock and a Rolls-Royce I envy the shop-girl in a coat and skirt whom I see jumping on the tailboard of a bus .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You mean that if need be you could earn your own living ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: What could you be ? A nurse or a typist . It 's nonsense . Luxury saps a woman 's nerve . And when she 's known it once it becomes a necessity .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That depends on the woman .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: When we 're young we think we 're different from everyone else , but when we grow a little older we discover we 're all very much of a muchness .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 're very kind to take so much trouble about me .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: It breaks my heart to think that you 're going to make the same pitiful mistake that I made .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , do n't say it was that , do n't , do n't .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Look at me , Elizabeth , and look at Hughie . Do you think it 's been a success ? If I had my time over again do you think I 'd do it again ? Do you think he would ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You see , you do n't know how much I love Teddie .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: And do you think I did n't love Hughie ? Do you think he did n't love me ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm sure he did .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , of course in the beginning it was heavenly . We felt so brave and adventurous and we were so much in love . The first two years were wonderful . People cut me , you know , but I did n't mind . I thought love was everything . It is a little uncomfortable when you come upon an old friend and go towards her eagerly , so glad to see her , and are met with an icy stare .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do you think friends like that are worth having ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Perhaps they 're not very sure of themselves . Perhaps they 're honestly shocked . It 's a test one had better not put one 's friends to if one can help it . It 's rather bitter to find how few one has .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But one has some .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Yes , they ask you to come and see them when they 're quite certain no one will be there who might object to meeting you . Or else they say to you : “ My dear , you know I 'm devoted to you , and I would n't mind at all , but my girl 's growing up — I 'm sure you understand ; you wo n't think it unkind of me if I do n't ask you to the house ? ”

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling .That does n't seem to me very serious .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: At first I thought it rather a relief , because it threw Hughie and me together more . But you know , men are very funny . Even when they are in love they 're not in love all day long . They want change and recreation .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm not inclined to blame them for that , poor dears .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Then we settled in Florence . And because we could n't get the society we 'd been used to we became used to the society we could get . Loose women and vicious men . Snobs who liked to patronise people with a handle to their names . Vague Italian Princes who were glad to borrow a few francs from Hughie and seedy countesses who liked to drive with me in the Cascine . And then Hughie began to hanker after his old life . He wanted to go big game shooting , but I dared not let him go . I was afraid he 'd never come back .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But you knew he loved you .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , what a blessed institution marriage is — for women , and what fools they are to meddle with it ! The Church is so wise to take its stand on the indi — indi —

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Solu —

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Bility of marriage . Believe me , it 's no joke when you have to rely only on yourself to keep a man . I could never afford to grow old . My dear , I 'll tell you a secret that I 've never told a living soul .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My hair is not naturally this colour .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Really .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I touch it up . You would never have guessed , would you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Nobody does . My dear , it 's white , prematurely of course , but white . I always think it 's a symbol of my life . Are you interested in symbolism ? I think it 's too wonderful .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't think I know very much about it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: However tired I 've been I 've had to be brilliant and gay . I 've never let Hughie see the aching heart behind my smiling eyes .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Amused and touched .You poor dear .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: And when I saw he was attracted by some one else the fear and the jealousy that seized me ! You see , I did n't dare make a scene as I should have done if I 'd been married — I had to pretend not to notice .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Taken aback .But do you mean to say he fell in love with anyone else ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Of course he did eventually .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Hardly knowing what to say .You must have been very unhappy .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , I was , dreadfully . Night after night I sobbed my heart out when Hughie told me he was going to play cards at the club and I knew he was with that odious woman . Of course , it was n't as if there were n't plenty of men who were only too anxious to console me . Men have always been attracted by me , you know .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , of course , I can quite understand it .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: But I had my self-respect to think of . I felt that whatever Hughie did I would do nothing that I should regret .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You must be very glad now .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , yes . Notwithstanding all my temptations I 've been absolutely faithful to Hughie in spirit .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't think I quite understand what you mean .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Well , there was a poor Italian boy , young Count Castel Giovanni , who was so desperately in love with me that his mother begged me not to be too cruel . She was afraid he 'd go into a consumption . What could I do ? And then , oh , years later , there was Antonio Melita . He said he 'd shoot himself unless I — well , you understand I could n't let the poor boy shoot himself .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: D'you think he really would have shot himself ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , one never knows , you know . Those Italians are so passionate . He was really rather a lamb . He had such beautiful eyes .

div.stage: ELIZABETH looks at her for a long time and a certain horror seizes her of this dissolute , painted old woman .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Hoarsely .Oh , but I think that 's — dreadful .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Are you shocked ? One sacrifices one 's life for love and then one finds that love does n't last . The tragedy of love is n't death or separation . One gets over them . The tragedy of love is indifference .

div.stage: ARNOLD comes in .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Can I have a little talk with you , Elizabeth ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Shall we go for a stroll in the garden ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: If you like .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: No , stay here . I 'm going out anyway .

div.stage: Exit LADY KITTY .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I want you to listen to me for a few minutes , Elizabeth . I was so taken aback by what you told me just now that I lost my head . I was rather absurd and I beg your pardon . I said things I regret .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , do n't blame yourself . I 'm sorry that I should have given you occasion to say them .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I want to ask you if you 've quite made up your mind to go .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Just now I seem to have said all that I did n't want to say and nothing that I did . I 'm stupid and tongue-tied . I never told you how deeply I loved you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , Arnold !

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Please let me speak now . It 's so very difficult . If I seemed absorbed in politics and the house , and so on , to the exclusion of my interest in you , I 'm dreadfully sorry . I suppose it was absurd of me to think you would take my great love for granted .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But , Arnold , I 'm not reproaching you .

lg.l: I 'm reproaching myself . I 've been tactless and neglectful . But
I do ask you to believe that it has n't been because I did n't love you .
Can you forgive me ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I do n't think that there 's anything to forgive .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It was n't till to-day when you talked of leaving me that I realised how desperately in love with you I was .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: After three years ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm so proud of you . I admire you so much . When I see you at a party , so fresh and lovely , and everybody wondering at you , I have a sort of little thrill because you 're mine , and afterwards I shall take you home .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , Arnold , you 're exaggerating .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I can n't imagine this house without you . Life seems on a sudden all empty and meaningless . Oh , Elizabeth , do n't you love me at all ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's much better to be honest . No .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Does n't my love mean anything to you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm very grateful to you . I 'm sorry to cause you pain . What would be the good of my staying with you when I should be wretched all the time ?

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Do you love that man as much as all that ? Does my unhappiness mean nothing to you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Of course it does . It breaks my heart . You see , I never knew I meant so much to you . I 'm so touched . And I 'm so sorry , Arnold , really sorry . But I can n't help myself .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Poor child , it 's cruel of me to torture you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , Arnold , believe me , I have tried to make the best of it . I 've tried to love you , but I can n't . After all , one either loves or one does n't . Trying is no help . And now I 'm at the end of my tether . I can n't help the consequences — I must do what my whole self yearns for .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: My poor child , I 'm so afraid you 'll be unhappy . I 'm so afraid you 'll regret .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You must leave me to my fate . I hope you 'll forget me and all the unhappiness I 've caused you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: There is a pause . ARNOLD walks up and down the room reflectively . He stops and faces her .If you love this man and want to go to him I 'll do nothing to prevent you . My only wish is to do what is best for you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Arnold , that 's awfully kind of you . If I 'm treating you badly at least I want you to know that I 'm grateful for all your kindness to me .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: But there 's one favour I should like you to do me . Will you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , Arnold , of course I 'll do anything I can .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Teddie has n't very much money . You 've been used to a certain amount of luxury , and I can n't bear to think that you should do without anything you 've had . It would kill me to think that you were suffering any hardship or privation .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , but Teddie can earn enough for our needs . After all , we do n't want much money .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I 'm afraid my mother 's life has n't been very easy , but it 's obvious that the only thing that 's made it possible is that Porteous was rich . I want you to let me make you an allowance of two thousand a year .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , no , I could n't think of it . It 's absurd .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: I beg you to accept it . You do n't know what a difference it will make .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's awfully kind of you , Arnold . It humiliates me to speak about it . Nothing would induce me to take a penny from you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Well , you can n't prevent me from opening an account at my bank in your name . The money shall be paid in every quarter whether you touch it or not , and if you happen to want it , it will be there waiting for you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You overwhelm me , Arnold . There 's only one thing I want you to do for me . I should be very grateful if you would divorce me as soon as you possibly can .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: No , I wo n't do that . But I 'll give you cause to divorce me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You !

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Yes . But of course you 'll have to be very careful for a bit . I 'll put it through as quickly as possible , but I 'm afraid you can n't hope to be free for over six months .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But , Arnold , your seat and your political career !

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Oh , well , my father gave up his seat under similar circumstances . He 's got along very comfortably without politics .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But they 're your whole life .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: After all one can n't have it both ways . You can n't serve God and Mammon . If you want to do the decent thing you have to be prepared to suffer for it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But I do n't want you to suffer for it .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: At first I rather hesitated at the scandal . But I daresay that was only weakness on my part . Under the circumstances I should have liked to keep out of the Divorce Court if I could .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Arnold , you 're making me absolutely miserable .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: What you said before dinner was quite right . It 's nothing for a man , but it makes so much difference to a woman . Naturally I must think of you first .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That 's absurd . It 's out of the question . Whatever there 's to pay I must pay it .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's not very much I 'm asking you , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm taking everything from you .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's the only condition I make . My mind is absolutely made up . I will never divorce you , but I will enable you to divorce me .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , Arnold , it 's cruel to be so generous .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: It 's not generous at all . It 's the only way I have of showing you how deep and passionate and sincere my love is for you .There is a silence . He holds out his hand .Good-night . I have a great deal of work to do before I go to bed .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: ARNOLD
sp.p: Do you mind if I kiss you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With agony .Oh , Arnold !

div.stage: He gravely kisses her on the forehead and then goes out . ELIZABETH stands lost in thought . She is shattered . LADY KITTY and PORTEOUS come in . LADY KITTY wears a cloak .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: You 're alone , Elizabeth ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: That note you asked me about , Lady Kitty , from Teddie . . .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He wanted to have a talk with me before he went away . He 's waiting for me in the summer house by the tennis court . Would Lord Porteous mind going down and asking him to come here ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Certainly . Certainly .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Forgive me for troubling you . But it 's very important .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: No trouble at all .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Hughie and I will leave you alone .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But I do n't want to be left alone . I want you to stay .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: What are you going to say to him ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Desperately .Please do n't ask me questions . I 'm so frightfully unhappy .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: My poor child !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , is n't life rotten ? Why can n't one be happy without making other people unhappy ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I wish I knew how to help you . I 'm simply devoted to you .She hunts about in her mind for something to do or say .Would you like my lip-stick ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Smiling through her tears .Thanks . I never use one .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , but just try . It 's such a comfort when you 're in trouble .

div.stage: Enter PORTEOUS and TEDDIE .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I brought him . He said he 'd be damned if he 'd come .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: When a lady sent for him ? Are these the manners of the young men of to-day ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: When you 've been solemnly kicked out of a house once I think it seems rather pushing to come back again as though nothing had happened .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Teddie , I want you to be serious .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Darling , I had such a rotten dinner at that pub . If you ask me to be serious on the top of that I shall cry .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do n't be idiotic , Teddie .Her voice faltering .I 'm so utterly wretched .

div.stage: He looks at her for a moment gravely .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I can n't come away with you , Teddie .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Looking away in embarrassment .I do n't love you enough .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Fiddle !

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: With a flash of anger .Do n't say “ Fiddle ” to me .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I shall say exactly what I like to you .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wo n't be bullied .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Now look here , Elizabeth , you know perfectly well that I 'm in love with you , and I know perfectly well that you 're in love with me . So what are you talking nonsense for ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Her voice breaking .I can n't say it if you 're cross with me .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Smiling very tenderly .I 'm not cross with you , silly .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: It 's harder still when you 're being rather an owl .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: With a chuckle .Am I mistaken in thinking you 're not very easy to please ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Oh , it 's monstrous . I was all wrought up and ready to do anything , and now you 've thoroughly put me out . I feel like a great big fat balloon that some one has put a long pin into .With a sudden look at him .Have you done it on purpose ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Upon my soul I do n't know what you 're talking about .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wonder if you 're really much cleverer than I think you are .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Taking her hands and making her sit down .Now tell me exactly what you want to say . By the way , do you want Lady Kitty and Lord Porteous to be here ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Elizabeth asked us to stay .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Oh , I do n't mind , bless you . I only thought you might feel rather in the way .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Frigidly .A gentlewoman never feels in the way , Mr. Luton .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Wo n't you call me Teddie ? Everybody does , you know .

div.stage: LADY KITTY tries to give him a withering look , but she finds it very difficult to prevent herself from smiling . TEDDIE strokes ELIZABETH 'S hands . She draws them away .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: No , do n't do that . Teddie , it was n't true when I said I did n't love you . Of course I love you . But Arnold loves me , too . I did n't know how much .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: What has he been saying to you ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: He 's been very good to me , and so kind . I did n't know he could be so kind . He offered to let me divorce him .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: That 's very decent of him .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But do n't you see , it ties my hands . How can I accept such a sacrifice ? I should never forgive myself if I profited by his generosity .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: If another man and I were devilish hungry and there was only one mutton chop between us , and he said , “ You eat it , ” I would n't waste a lot of time arguing . I 'd wolf it before he changed his mind .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Do n't talk like that . It maddens me . I 'm trying to do the right thing .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You 're not in love with Arnold ; you 're in love with me . It 's idiotic to sacrifice your life for a slushy sentiment .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: After all , I did marry him .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Well , you made a mistake . A marriage without love is no marriage at all .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I made the mistake . Why should he suffer for it ? If anyone has to suffer it 's only right that I should .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: What sort of a life do you think it would be with him ? When two people are married it 's very difficult for one of them to be unhappy without making the other unhappy too .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I can n't take advantage of his generosity .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I daresay he 'll get a lot of satisfaction out of it .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You 're being beastly , Teddie . He was simply wonderful . I never knew he had it in him . He was really noble .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You are talking rot , Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I wonder if you 'd be capable of acting like that .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Acting like what ?

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: What would you do if I were married to you and came and told you I loved somebody else and wanted to leave you ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: You have very pretty blue eyes , Elizabeth . I 'd black first one and then the other . And after that we 'd see .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You damned brute !

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: I 've often thought I was n't quite a gentleman . Had it ever struck you ?

div.stage: They look at one another for a while .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You know , you are taking an unfair advantage of me . I feel as if I came to you quite unsuspectingly and when I was n't looking you kicked me on the shins .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Do n't you think we 'd get on rather well together ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Elizabeth 's a fool if she do n't stick to her husband . It 's bad enough for the man , but for the woman — it 's damnable . I hold no brief for Arnold . He plays bridge like a foot . Saving your presence , Kitty , I think he 's a prig .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Poor dear , his father was at his age . I daresay he 'll grow out of it .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: But you stick to him , Elizabeth , stick to him . Man is a gregarious animal . We 're members of a herd . If we break the herd 's laws we suffer for it . And we suffer damnably .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , Elizabeth , my dear child , do n't go . It 's not worth it . It 's not worth it . I tell you that , and I 've sacrificed everything to love .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: In a whisper .Elizabeth .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: I can n't face it . It 's asking too much of me . Let 's say good-bye to one another , Teddie . It 's the only thing to do . And have pity on me . I 'm giving up all my hope of happiness .

div.stage: He goes up to her and looks into her eyes .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: But I was n't offering you happiness . I do n't think my sort of love tends to happiness . I 'm jealous . I 'm not a very easy man to get on with . I 'm often out of temper and irritable . I should be fed to the teeth with you sometimes , and so would you be with me . I daresay we 'd fight like cat and dog , and sometimes we 'd hate each other . Often you 'd be wretched and bored stiff and lonely , and often you 'd be frightfully homesick , and then you 'd regret all you 'd lost . Stupid women would be rude to you because we 'd run away together . And some of them would cut you . I do n't offer you peace and quietness . I offer you unrest and anxiety . I do n't offer you happiness . I offer you love .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Stretching out her arms .You hateful creature , I absolutely adore you !

div.stage: He throws his arms round her and kisses her passionately on the lips .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Of course the moment he said he 'd give her a black eye I knew it was finished .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Good-humouredly .You are a fool , Kitty .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: I know I am , but I can n't help it .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Let 's make a bolt for it now .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Shall we ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: This minute .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You 're damned fools , both of you , damned fools ! If you like you can have my car .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: That 's awfully kind of you . As a matter of fact I got it out of the garage . It 's just along the drive .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Indignantly .How do you mean , you got it out of the garage ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Well , I thought there 'd be a lot of bother , and it seemed to me the best thing would be for Elizabeth and me not to stand upon the order of our going , you know . Do it now . An excellent motto for a business man .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Do you mean to say you were going to steal my car ?

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Not exactly . I was only going to bolshevise it , so to speak .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: I 'm speechless . I 'm absolutely speechless .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Hang it all , I could n't carry Elizabeth all the way to London . She 's so damned plump .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: You dirty dog !

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Spluttering .Well , well , well ! . . .Helplessly .I like him , Kitty , it 's no good pretending I do n't . I like him .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: The moon 's shining , Elizabeth . We 'll drive all through the night .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: They 'd better go to San Michele . I 'll wire to have it got ready for them .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: That 's where we went when Hughie and I . . .Faltering .Oh , you dear things , how I envy you !

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Mopping his eyes .Now do n't cry , Kitty . Confound you , do n't cry .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Come , darling .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: But I can n't go like this .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Nonsense ! Lady Kitty will lend you her cloak . Wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Taking it off .You 're capable of tearing it off my back if I do n't .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Putting the cloak on ELIZABETH .And we 'll buy you a tooth-brush in London in the morning .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: She must write a note for Arnold . I 'll put it on her pincushion .

sp.speaker: TEDDIE
sp.p: Pincushion be blowed ! Come , darling . We 'll drive through the dawn and through the sunrise .

sp.speaker: ELIZABETH
sp.p: Kissing LADY KITTY and PORTEOUS .Good-bye . Good-bye .

div.stage: TEDDIE stretches out his hand and she takes it . Hand in hand they go out into the night .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh , Hughie , how it all comes back to me ! Will they suffer all we suffered ? And have we suffered all in vain ?

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: My dear , I do n't know that in life it matters so much what you do as what you are . No one can learn by the experience of another because no circumstances are quite the same . If we made rather a hash of things perhaps it was because we were rather trivial people . You can do anything in this world if you 're prepared to take the consequences , and consequences depend on character .

div.stage: Enter CHAMPION-CHENEY , rubbing his hands . He is as pleased as Punch .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Well , I think I 've settled the hash of that young man .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: You have to get up very early in the morning to get the better of your humble servant .

div.stage: There is the sound of a car starting .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: It sounds like a car . I expect it 's your chauffeur taking one of the maids for a joy-ride .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: Whose hash are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: Mr. Edward Luton 's , my dear Hughie . I told Arnold exactly what to do and he 's done it . What makes a prison ? Why , bars and bolts . Remove them and a prisoner wo n't want to escape . Clever , I flatter myself .

sp.speaker: PORTEOUS
sp.p: You were always that , Clive , but at the moment you 're obscure .

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: I told Arnold to go to Elizabeth and tell her she could have her freedom . I told him to sacrifice himself all along the line . I know what women are . The moment every obstacle was removed to her marriage with Teddie Luton , half the allurement was gone .

sp.speaker: LADY KITTY
sp.p: Arnold did that ?

sp.speaker: C. - C
sp.p: He followed my instructions to the letter . I 've just seen him . She 's shaken . I 'm willing to bet five hundred pounds to a penny that she wo n't bolt . A downy old bird , eh ? Downy 's the word . Downy .

div.stage: He begins to laugh . They laugh , too . Presently they are all three in fits of laughter .
The Curtain Falls
